item.title: Black, Native American and Fighting for Recognition in Indian Country
item.description: Enslaved people were also driven west along the Trail of Tears. After a historic Supreme Court ruling, their descendants are fighting to be counted as tribal members.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

item.title: Website Crashes and Cyberattacks Welcome Students Back to School
item.description: With many districts across the country opting for online learning, a range of technical issues marred the first day of classes.
item.dc:creator: Dan Levin and Kate Taylor
item.media:description: Many of the nation’s school districts faced technical challenges on Tuesday while starting the academic year remotely.

item.title: Colorado Weather: Roasting Yesterday, Snowing Today
item.description: Temperatures plunged more than 50 degrees overnight as an Arctic air mass drove into the Denver area, bringing a very early winter storm on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:description: Smoke from the Cameron Peak wildfire occluded the skyline of downtown Denver on Sunday.

item.title: Harrowing Helicopter Rescues as California Wildfires Rage
item.description: The two pilots who led a weekend rescue, both military veterans, said it was the most challenging flying they have done in their careers.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:description: Dozens of people were evacuated by a California National Guard helicopter on Saturday after being trapped by the Creek Fire in the Sierra National Forest.

item.title: Trump Admits Minimizing the Virus, Woodward Reports in New Book
item.description: The president didn’t “want to create a panic” even as he said it was more dangerous than the flu, he told the journalist Bob Woodward.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: President Trump gave the journalist Bob Woodward extensive access in hopes the eventual book would be “positive” in his eyes.

item.title: Trump Attacked Generals as Weak and Too Focused on Allies, Woodward’s Book Says
item.description: The journalist Bob Woodward’s “Rage,” which will be released next week, recounts tense conflicts between the president and his senior leaders.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: “There may be a time when we have to take collective action,” said Jim Mattis, the former defense secretary, according to the book.

item.title: A Year of Heartbreak and Bloodshed at Fort Hood
item.description: More Fort Hood soldiers have died in homicides than in battle since 2016, and officials and family members are struggling to understand why.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Schools Reopening During Coronavirus Pandemic: Dorms and Super Spreaders
item.description: Colleges are struggling to deal with outbreaks on campus.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
item.category: State University of New York at Oneonta

item.title: How Are You Keeping Your Students Engaged?
item.description: Teachers: We want to hear your strategies.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Ron Gorchov, Painter Who Challenged Viewers’ Perceptions, Dies at 90
item.description: Seeking “a new kind of visual space” and using a vivid palette, he stacked multiple canvases with gently curved, round-cornered tops.
item.dc:creator: Roberta Smith

item.title: Drag Queens Deliver Dinner and a Show in San Francisco
item.description: Oasis, a cabaret and nightclub, closed in March because of the coronavirus pandemic. Now its drag queens are bringing food and a curbside performance to people’s front doors.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León and Kelsey McClellan

item.title: California Wildfires Tracker: Live Updates as Smoke Blocks Out Sun in Northern California
item.description: Strong winds were likely to continue to fuel the extraordinary number of fires burning in California, Oregon and Washington State.

item.title: Wildfires in California: More Than 2 Million Acres Have Burned
item.description: Wednesday: Another update on the raging wildfires. Also: More counties can ease restrictions; and a look at school district-supported learning pods.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Marie Tae McDermott
item.media:description: A firefighter battled the Creek Fire in the Shaver Lake community of Fresno County on Monday.

item.title: The N.R.A.’s new candidate grades show a continuing decline in support.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: The N.R.A. has been embroiled in a series of legal and reputational battles, and gun control groups have begun to catch up in terms of political clout.

item.title: Michigan seemed to be slipping from Trump, but now he’s competing again there.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:description: President Trump toured Ford Rawsonville Components Plant in Ypsilanti, Mich., in May. Both Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Mr. Trump are visiting Michigan this week.

item.title: A New Hampshire lawmaker, Dan Feltes, beat a Sanders-backed candidate in the Democratic primary for governor.
item.description: The victories by Gov. Chris Sununu, a Republican, and Senator Jeanne Shaheen, a Democrat, reinforced the state’s battleground status. Corky Messner, who was endorsed by President Trump, won his primary to challenge Ms. Shaheen.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel and Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Kristopher Radder/The Brattleboro Reformer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: New Hampshire primary voters chose candidates for governor and Senate on Tuesday.

item.title: A Florida poll found the candidates tied, but with shifting sources of support.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cooper
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham and others listened as President Trump delivered remarks in Jupiter, Fla., on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. to Reduce Troop Levels in Iraq to 3,000
item.description: The long-planned cuts maintain a U.S. counterterrorism force in Iraq but help fulfill President Trump’s goal to reduce overseas deployments.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. Army soldiers at an air base northwest of Kirkuk in northern Iraq in March.

item.title: Small Earthquake Rattles New Jersey
item.description: The 3.1-magnitude earthquake shook an area about a mile south of East Freehold in Monmouth County. There were no reports of damage or injuries.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: A United States Geological Survey map showing the location of the earthquake that struck New Jersey early Wednesday.

item.title: The ‘Great Environmentalist’ President
item.description: Trump seeks to muddy the waters on his climate record: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: The Virus Moves Off Campus
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A student leaving campus housing at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill last month.

item.title: Covid-19 News: Live Updates
item.description: Two top health officials appeared before a Senate panel the day after AstraZeneca announced a hold in a vaccine trial. Britain will ban most gatherings of more than six people starting Monday.

item.title: Why Coronavirus Tests Come With Surprise Bills
item.description: Congress sought to ensure that patients would not face costs connected to the virus. But rules are not always being followed.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kliff
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura for The New York Times
item.media:description: A drive-through testing site in Houston last month. Nationwide, people have been hit with unexpected fees and denied claims related to coronavirus tests.

item.title: AstraZeneca Pauses Vaccine Trial for Safety Review
item.description: The company halted late-stage trials of its coronavirus vaccine because of a serious suspected adverse reaction in a participant.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu and Katie Thomas
item.media:description: Because of safety concerns, AstraZeneca paused late-stage trials of its coronavirus vaccine, which is being tested in locations like São Paolo, Brazil.

item.title: A Police Officer Shot a 13-Year-Old With Autism in Salt Lake City
item.description: The authorities said the officer shot the boy while responding to a call about a “violent psych issue.” The teenager, Linden Cameron, was fleeing and did not have a weapon, his mother said.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: Salt Lake City Police

item.title: Federal Report Warns of Financial Havoc From Climate Change
item.description: A report commissioned by President Trump’s Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued dire warnings about climate change’s impact on financial markets.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Cindy Yamanaka/The Orange County Register, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Firefighters extinguished hot spots in an area destroyed by the El Dorado wildfire near Yucaipa, Calif., on Monday.

item.title: Democrats Fear Partisan Slant at Postal Service as Trump Allies Dominate Board
item.description: The five Republicans on the seven-member board have taken a hands-on role in trying to defend the agency against accusations that it is trying to help the president win a second term by sabotaging voting by mail.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Hailey Fuchs and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:description: Robert Duncan, the chairman of the Postal Service’s board of governors, assured lawmakers last month during a hearing on Capitol Hill that he was committed to doing his job according to “the public interest.”

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Drugmakers pledged to not distribute a vaccine until it had been thoroughly tested.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga

item.title: Republicans Push Scaled-Back Stimulus Plan as Impasse on Virus Aid Persists
item.description: The economic recovery measure Republicans presented on Tuesday is a fraction of the size of their original offer and was immediately dismissed by Democrats as inadequate.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I will make sure every Senate Democrat who has said they’d like to reach an agreement gets the opportunity to walk the walk,” Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, said on Tuesday.

item.title: Democrats Flip Open the Health Care Playbook
item.description: Coronavirus ads are one thing, but Democrats are also bringing back the messaging that worked so well for them in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: 7 Fatally Shot at California House Where 1,000 Pounds of Marijuana Is Found
item.description: The illegal marijuana trade remains a constant and deadly presence, the Riverside County sheriff said.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah and Allyson Waller
item.media:description: The porch of a house where seven people were found shot in Aguanga, Calif., a rural, unincorporated area of Riverside County.

item.title: Dallas Police Chief Resigns in Wake of Policing Protests
item.description: The chief, U. Reneé Hall, faced eroding support on the City Council stemming from the department’s handling of public protests over African-Americans and policing.
item.dc:creator: David Montgomery
item.media:description: Chief U. Reneé Hall said on Tuesday that she would resign from the Dallas Police Department.

item.title: Trump, Calling Himself ‘the No. 1 Environmental President,’ Green Washes His Record
item.description: President Trump traveled to Florida to declare himself “a great environmentalist,” extending a moratorium on offshore oil drilling that his administration had moved to end.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: President Trump signed an environmental order on offshore drilling at an event in Jupiter, Fla., on Tuesday.

item.title: Manhattan’s Office Buildings Are Empty. But for How Long?
item.description: As they grow accustomed to working from home, many businesses are delaying signing new leases until rents drop and the pandemic passes.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell and Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

item.title: In Georgia, Officials Are Investigating Hundreds of Cases of Double Voting
item.description: Georgia’s secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger, said that 1,000 people voted twice in the state’s June primary and August runoff elections, and warned that “we will prosecute.”
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brad Raffensperger, Georgia’s secretary of state, held a news conference Tuesday to announce that investigations were underway in 100 of the state’s 159 counties.

item.title: A look at Douglas Emhoff’s legal career as he seeks to become the nation’s first Second Gentleman.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul, Kenneth P. Vogel and Danny Hakim
item.media:description: Douglas Emhoff with his wife, Senator Kamala Harris of California, after she accepted the Democratic nomination for vice president last month.

item.title: Sununu and Shaheen Cruise in New Hampshire Primaries for Governor and Senate
item.description: Gov. Chris Sununu, a Republican, will face Dan Feltes, a Democrat, in the general election. Senator Jeanne Shaheen is being challenged by Corky Messner, who was endorsed by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Kristopher Radder/The Brattleboro Reformer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: New Hampshire primary voters chose candidates for governor and Senate on Tuesday.

item.title: President Trump returns to the politics of fear, and hopes it will be more effective than it was in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:description: President Trump and Republican strategists are trying to appeal to swing voters by using fear based tactics against Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the Democrats.

item.title: Will Doug Emhoff’s Legal Career Be an Issue for the Biden-Harris Ticket?
item.description: Mr. Emhoff, the husband of Senator Kamala Harris, has a long record as a litigator at two of the nation’s top firms, posing potential conflicts that could draw scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul, Kenneth P. Vogel and Danny Hakim
item.media:description: Douglas Emhoff with his wife, Senator Kamala Harris, after she accepted the Democratic nomination for vice president last month.

item.title: The Climate Connection to California’s Wildfires
item.description: As fires spread through California during a global pandemic, read some of our past coverage about what’s causing them and what might help contain them.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters used drip torches to start a controlled burn to contain the Creek Fire in Shaver Lake, Calif., on Sunday.
